Award.AbstractNarration:
The IAS/Park City Mathematics Institute (PCMI) is a three-week summer school in the mathematical sciences, held each July in Park City, Utah. Its primary goal is to promote the development of mathematics students, teachers and researchers through concurrent overlapping programs of undergraduate and graduate study, teacher development, and mathematical research activities. This award supports five components of PCMI. Three of these components are the Research Program, the Graduate Summer School and the Undergraduate Summer School, that are organized around a single area of contemporary mathematical research. The Research Program and Graduate Summer School are led by world-renowned mathematicians. Lecturers in the graduate and undergraduate programs are world leaders in their specialties. All are chosen for their expository abilities. A fourth component, the Undergraduate Faculty Program, considers that year's mathematical research topic in light of undergraduate education. It is lead by a specialist who is an excellent teacher at the undergraduate level. PCMI contributes to the development of under-represented minorities in the STEM disciplines through the fifth funded component, a one-week Workshop for Mentors of Undergraduate Research by Minority Students. Workshop participants develop research projects suitable for use in undergraduate research programs. Workshop participants go on to lead undergraduate research programs for under-represented minorities after attending PCMI. One key goal is to build a pipeline of minority students who are prepared to participate in PCMI's undergraduate and graduate summer schools. The dissemination of PCMI activities to the wider mathematical community of graduate students and researchers is accomplished through its publication program. Polished versions of the lectures from each year's Graduate Summer School constitute a volume published by the American Mathematical Society (AMS). Quite often, one of the undergraduate lecture series, or the Undergraduate Faculty program leads to an innovative undergraduate text, also published by the AMS. PCMI is also now embarking on a series of volumes incorporating material developed in its program for secondary school teachers.

The research themes for PCMI vary from year to year. Each theme is chosen to reflect current trends of high importance in the mathematical community and is based on the identification of organizers who take seriously the synergistic nature of PCMI. The research themes for the first three programs that will be funded by this award and their organizers are as follows:

2015: Geometry of Moduli Spaces and Representation Theory; Roman Bezrukavnikov, Alexander Braverman,
and Zhiwei Yun

2016: The Mathematics of Data; Anna Gilbert and Michael Mahoney

2017: Random Matrices; Alexei Borodin, Alice Guionnet, and Ivan Corwin.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The IAS/PCMI program is now 30 years old. It is a fully vertically integrated summer institute uniquely aimed toward the entire mathematical community, from senior researchers, though graduate and undergraduate students, faculty at undergraduate focused colleges and universities, faculty who wish to deepen their ability to promote inclusion and diversity in their classrooms, and K-12 teachers. All but this last component are NSF funded. Each year the mathematical focus is different: a group of four or five organizers, specialists in that research area, shape the research and graduate components of the program.  

The fields represented during the five years of this grant period were:  Geometry of Moduli Spaces and Representation Theory, The Mathematics of Data, Random Matrices, Harmonic Analysis, and Quantum Field Theory and Manifold Invariants. The scientific level of the meetings is very high: the workshop is designed for the dissemination of recent work in the area and to provide a forum for high-level interaction. The lecturers and topics for the graduate minicourses are carefully chosen to help train a new generation of students and young researchers in that field. The graduate lectures are later published as a monograph by the AMS, and videos of these lectures are now archived and made available on the PCMI web page; these volumes and videos are widely used as entry points into research in each of these fields. 

The intellectual merit of the program is very high: around 160 top-level mathematicians and students, including researchers and students from a broad spectrum of institutions, are brought together for this intensive program. The mathematical themes are chosen to be both timely and particularly active ones in mathematics or at the intersection of mathematics with other disciplines. The interactions cultivated at PCMI consistently foster an intellectual intensity and lead to important mathematical progress in these fields.  

The PCMI program has significant broader impact as well. It includes a superior training program in central mathematical disciplines, and serves as a major pipeline for students and young researchers to enter or move up in that field. It provides extensive opportunities for these participants to interact and build networks with one another as well as with senior researchers working in that same area.

Other NSF-funded components of PCMI include a set of courses and activities aimed at undergraduate students, another aimed at the professional development of faculty at undergraduate-focused institutions, and a workshop for faculty interested in the theory and practice of inclusion and diversity in the classroom.

There is a separate non-NSF funded component to PCMI: a K-12 teacher development program. Each year over 60 teachers convene for a series of courses, some focused on mathematical content and others focused on pedagogy. The former of course increase the knowledge of the subject and their passion for it, and help them develop new approaches to curricular development. The latter gives an opportunity for group work on developing the most effective pedagogical practices.  Participants are encouraged and given tools to be master teachers in their home districts and to spread what they have learned at PCMI to other teachers. They develop a much broader web of relationships in the teacher community which is often sustained far into the future.

Perhaps the most novel aspect of PCMI is its greatest ambition: the participants from these various different groups work in close juxtaposition, both on their own projects and also on a number of shared activities. All of this creates an appreciation amongst all participants for the nature and importance of the work carried about by the others, and maybe even more particularly, for the challenges these others face in their professional lives. This may be the only occasion for senior researchers to interact closely with a group of high school teachers, or vice versa. This is surely a broad impact of the program.
